comments.commentBody:
Headline is WRONG...The SAINTS beat Peyton Manning...period

He should not have been league MVP

Brees showed everyone tonight that he is the better quarterback

Stop with the Peyton worship....same with Phil Mickelson the media loves them, not so much the fans

Dudes and Dudettes:  wise up:  the Who were always over-rated.  Good musicians, hard-driving rock--yes.  But, even in their prime, their chief deficiency:  no really memorable SONGS, for the simple reason that they never had significant MELODIC sense.  "Pinball Wizard" is the archetype of this:  good beat, amusing concept--but literally monotonous (monotone-ous).  Back in the day, this band got a lot of mileage out of smashing their guitars:  good show, on the surface--but without musical substance.  Their inept performance tonight served the purpose of removing the veil from their actual, deeper, mediocrity.  I hope they don't embarrass themselves in public again.

Mr. Bronner and his son, I am assuming, are American citizens. The question arises as to why, a citizen of the United States, a country  which has its overstreched defense forces fighting two wars, would join the defense forces on another country. My apologies to the Bronners if they are, in fact, Israeli citizens, in which case of course the young man's decision to become a soldier in his country's army is a commendable one.  The conflict of interest issue is a no brainer, and the fact that Mr. Keller does not see it as such is not surprising to anyone who regularly reads the NYT.

Mark:

The lyricist of "It Had to Be You" is Gus Kahn, not Sammy Cahn. I was stuck on Cahn, too, finally realized it had to be the other one for QUARKS to work.

thanks everyone. the asterisks sort of had to be there because the theme answers weren't all the longest entries in the grid. (my favorite entry, FAIR'S FAIR, is one of the seven 9-letter answers, but isn't a theme answer.)

meg, you may not know the word KOAN (two syllables), but you're surely familiar with the idea. perhaps the most famous koan is "what is the sound of one hand clapping?" there are others that are slightly less catchy, like the one where the student asks "master, does a dog have buddha nature?" and the master replies: "wu."

sonya: yes, but not really. i mean, you could "solve" the puzzle in microsoft excel or something like that. to my knowledge there is no user interface specifically designed for diagramless crosswords. it probably wouldn't be all that different to do from a programming perspective, but the drawback is that you'd have a very limited target audience. once every six weeks in the NYT, plus brendan emmett quigley's excellent book ... that's literally all of the diagramless crosswords i know of.

I liked the theme, enjoyed just about everything. No real problems solving it, a least nothing that paying attention, retaining focus, writing more neatly, better hand/eye coordination, an encyclopedic vocabulary, and having far more mental acuity wouldn't help.

The thing that doesn't work is the idea that LGTH and Width are opposites. Is there a length/width continuum? Is Depth another opposite of Width? Just doesn't work for me. If Martin were to appear on my front porch accompanied by Mssrs. (and/or Mmes and/or Mlles) Webster, Funk, Wagnalls, Oxford-English, Miriam, Collegiate, Roget, Bartlett, Strunk, and a panel of length-width specialists armed with incontrovertible proof -- I would remain unconvinced.

A Win for the Saints and the City of New Orleans. We have been celebrating for the two weeks before today and now will celebrate for the next 12 days.
Come experience the JOY.
Geaux Saints!!!

I'm happy for New Orleans (even though this win will not change the social ills that have plagued the city for decades), BUT

This was kind of a boring game....

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Dave... as Howard Beck belatedly found out, Nate shooting at his own hoop was pretty harmless. For one it occurred after the quarter ended. For another even had it been in the run of play it wouldn't have counted... a point lost on many of Nate's critics.

If D'Antoni wants to discipline Nate for his on-court celebrations then that's fine... that's the coach's prerogative. Mind you, as I pointed out in an earlier discussion on the same point... I seem to recall Mark Jackson doing helicopters up and down the court as a rookie and everyone loved his "youthful enthusiasm". But D'Antoni is not Pitino... so again, I won't complain about that. What I found was ridiculous was benching him an entire month and saying dumb stuff like he doesn't know when Nate would next play again.

As for the "D'Antoni hating" talk... I'll address that along with Chuck's assertion that the Knicks were "winning" without Nate. Yeah they were winning so much that D'Antoni had to relent and reinsert Nate into the lineup... all he did was single-handedly win the Atlanta game for them. It was pure happenstance that the "winning" coincided with the benching... as should be apparent to anyone with a basketball IQ. The real factor was that D'Antoni changed his tactics as mentioned above. Once he decided to maximize possessions, rather than chuck it up every "Seven Seconds or Less" then the team responded. D'Antoni admittedly wasn't given much to work with... but what he was given he woefully mismanaged. Even in the midst of losing he (along with Walsh, no doubt) eschewed developing younger players in the vain hopes of winning. Winning what?? How much have our two draft picks (Hill and Douglas) played? Are either of them better than Ty Lawson or Brandon Jennings?

This is the genius braintrust that you want to celebrate? Have we become so used to losing that we now cheer mediocrity? If the Knicks let Robinson go all he'll do is blossom... the way Jamal Crawford, Channing Frye and Zach Randolph has elsewhere.

Alas, I don't thing your "researchers" have thought this instrument through.  They should bring the subject into the process, gaining his/her interest and enthusiasm, before asking what they've mistakenly allowed to be the very first question, namely to paste a link for the very last article emailed.  I've mailed at least 7-8 in the last 3 days, don't remember which was last, and have no incentive to dig back to try to find out.  So I closed the window before providing a single answer.  I doubt I'll be the only one.  This challenge is quite common in social science research.  These researchers probably usually do a better job of design when they want to obtain a reasonable response rate from their sample.  Maybe they just figured you had a captive audience and it didn't really matter.  Hope the research objective wasn't an important one...

Found the survey strange and somewhat awkward. First, you have to have a link to the last article you shared, which requires either searching the NYT site or rummaging through email.

The questions are the type that leave you looking for an answer that isn't offered as one of the multiple choice responses.

Second, the emotive-content questions remind me of the types of questions they used to tell moderators NOT to ask in focus groups, but to try to elicit through other questions. Asking them directly, seems strange.

Next up, a survey asking: Which animal did this NYT article most remind you of: A gorilla, an owl, a rat ....

But good luck with your survey anyway.

I didn't like this survey. The first question was flawed in assuming that I had emailed the article to just one person. I typically send articles to multiple people, as I think others do.

The subsequent questions felt like they were leading me into the researcher's preconceived notions of why people forward articles.

Finally, it seemed too focused on the means of sharing (email). Increasingly, I share times articles via facebook, linkedin and other avenues outside of traditional email.

The only times I've emailed NYT articles are when they are so RIDICULOUS and unfair. Case in point: today's story on "My Way" and karaoke-loving Filipinos. I've found that the Times does this a lot -- takes a few isolated and bizarre incidents in some country (this one is the Philippines, other times it's China or Japan or India) and reports on it as if it were some national phenomenon. Makes the country in question sound completely weird and "other."

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Richard Attanasio (and his cosigner, CL) don't know what he's talking about with his criticism of Pat Ewing.

It's beyond silly to say that his career "never lived up to his physical assets" when the guy:

- Made himself into an NBA Hall of Famer.
- Was an 11-time NBA All-Star
- Named one of the NBA's 50 Greatest Players of All time
- Was a 2-Time Olympic Gold Medalist
- Consistently was in the NBA's top ten in field goal percentage (kinda refutes the whole "he spent too much time shooting from outside talk).
- Consistently was in the Top Ten in blocks... again, not sure how he did all of that 18-feet from the basket

... in fact I could go on and on putting up his stats but really the issue is just too silly to even bother arguing about it.
As I stated in my pre game post, he typed boastfully, the confluence of Katrina, Haiti,and Voodoo would be the overwhelming determinants in  the preordained outcome.. Shucks !

SO happy for the NO Saints and especially Drew Brees.  He and his team fought hard for this win and they deserved it so much.  Drew never got the chance for a Super Bowl when he was with the San Diego Chargers and I just hope the Chargers learned something today.

This is a good place to eat Mexican food. I enjoyed my fish tacos and very much enjoyed my margaritas.

Joanne

My husband and I generally like to stay off the beaten path whenever we travel.  When we first travelled to Santa Fe, wee stayed just outside of Santa Fe at the Highfeather Ranch, a B&B in Cerrillos.  Absolutely amazing!  MaryAnn is such a generous hostess and a wonderful cook.  As visitors to NM, we found that Cerrillos gave us a more genuine NM experience.  Be sure to visit Mary's Bar, as well as historic Madrid, NM!

What amuses me more than anything is the slide show appending the article about the win.
All the photographs make it clear that the Colts were EXPECTED to win.
SURPRISE!!
Believe Dat!

The only thing missing in Manning's choke record: Throw a pick six in the 4th quarter of a Superbowl to give away the game. Resume is complete now.
And yes, Brady is better, WAY better than that.
No more Mr. Nice Guy
Well, that's that.
Will it hurt?

Said during Halftime:

"I can't believe I ate the whole bag."
Five famous simple words from Frank Sinatra in closing a 1968 song may be quite appropriate for many as their own final words: "I did it my way."
